awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Expanding the repertoire of chemical tools to study and characterize bacterial Gcn5-related N-acetyltransferase functions
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation Research in Undergraduate Institutions award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program funds Dr. Misty L. Kuhn from San Francisco State University (SFSU) and Dr. Daniel P. Becker from Loyola University Chicago to create biochemical tools to study enzymes in the family of Gcn5-related N-acetyltransferase (GNAT) proteins of unknown function from the soil microorganism, Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Specifically, these tools are used in combination with structure determinations via X-ray crystallography to gain a greater understanding of how molecules bind to GNATs. Since relatively little is known about the structure/function relationship of GNATs from P. aeruginosa, this work fills this gap in knowledge. Determining these functions is important because human welfare depends on healthy agriculture.  This project enhances the research infrastructure at SFSU by establishing its first protein crystallization resource and increasing the repertoire of sophisticated biochemistry skills of underrepresented minority and disadvantaged undergraduate students.
 
The goal of this project is to improve the functional annotation of P. aeruginosa GNATs of unknown function using a combination of protein X-ray crystallography, molecular modeling, organic synthesis, and enzymology. The architecture of the acceptor site of several GNAT proteins are probed using biochemical tools and X-ray crystallography. Active site residues that are critical for catalysis and substrate specificity are identified and tested using molecular modeling, site-directed mutagenesis, and enzyme kinetics. The results of this project provides the foundational knowledge to categorize experimentally uncharacterized members of the GNAT family and improve computational functional annotation of GNATs of unknown function.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The work supported by this grant is considered fundamental, but critical. The fundamental knowledge we have gained in our studies (determining structures and functions of these proteins, elucidating the architecture and importance of key residues in the protein active site, investigating new kinetic mechanisms for this family of proteins, and developing new tools and procedures for examining how they bind and turn over their substrates) is required to more deeply understand how proteins in this extremely large superfamily work. This is critical as we seek to understand how they are involved in molecular processes across all domains of life, learn how they enable known and new mechanisms of antibiotic drug resistance, and use them to engineer new enzymes that modify complex molecules to simplify organic syntheses and enable greener chemical processes. Furthermore, to keep up with the explosive pace of recent computational methods for protein structure prediction, functional studies that determine residue requirements for chemical and kinetic mechanisms and substrate recognition will become even more important. The results of our studies have revealed new insight into all aspects of this dilemma and will surely be used as a knowledge base to continue to investigate this family of proteins more deeply in the future. Finally, this work has supported the scientific development of numerous undergraduate and Masters students in STEM disciplines at a public state university who are becoming the next generation of scientists who will continue to solve complex problems. In my mind they are already scientists because they have been involved in all aspects of the work supported by this grant and have participated in authentic research. Their innovative ideas, hard work, scientific rigor, and determination have been critical components to the success of these projects, and they should be recognized for their contributions.


Last Modified: 04/26/2022
Modified by: Misty L Kuhn
